The Anti-Defamation League has designated Catskill Middle School as “No Place For Hate.”

No Place for Hate is a school-directed program that builds inclusive and safe communities in which all students can thrive. It empowers students, faculty, and administrators to stand together against hate and bullying by incorporating new and existing programs under one powerful message that all students deserve respect and a place to belong. To earn designation as a No Place for Hate school, CMS conducted a needs assessment, undertook anti-bias and bullying prevention training, formed a student-involved No Place for Hate committee that designed and implemented school-wide anti-bias and bullying prevention activities, and had the student body sign a school-wide Resolution of Respect.

She showed the students how they could make patterns and marks on natural materials with the dyes and assisted them in the process. The art students plan to work alongside the students from the Fashion class by making dyed scarves for our school’s Fashion Show happening this May. This way the art classes can take part in the show, learning a new technique by dying the scarves that will be worn in the show. “This cross-curricular project will hopefully be the first of many,” said art teacher Mrs. Doney, who invited Ms. Klompas in to work with her students. Special thanks to the Catskill Educational Foundation, which provided the grant for the materials and to have Ms. Klompas come to our school for the day.

post_text: The CMS Life Skills class hosted their annual Holiday Feast on December 11. They began the year learning how to read recipes, and put new vocabulary words like mince, chop, tradition, bake, barbecue, baste, boil, and broil to use as they followed different recipes. They learned math and measuring skills as they progressed to making a menu for their event. The students studied the food groups and the different sections of the grocery store. They made a grocery list, looked up and compared prices, calculated the tax to estimate the cost of their dinner, and practiced writing checks. The students then learned how to write an invitation and this week will be writing Thank You notes to their guests. The goal of the program is for the students to be able to carry this knowledge into their life after school. They enjoy and continue to be motivated by this part of the curriculum.

The CES Literacy Fair was a fun filled family night promoting the love of reading and writing. This Catskill Educational Foundation and PTA sponsored event ensured all children went home with new books and fantastic prizes for students who completed an at-home reading log. On December 6, students walked through the familiar CES doors and found themselves strolling through the North Pole in a Winter Wonderland. Over 75 students in grades pre-K to second attended this great event! The children enjoyed read-alouds and literature based activities presented by over 25 of our very own teacher and staff volunteers. Nights like the Literacy Fair help CES students become better readers at school and at home. Each child received his or her own bag of "snow much fun" books and literacy tools.

The night was more frosty fun than we could have imagined! It was a wonderful night where students warmed their hearts with reading, seeing their families and teachers as life-long readers. Keep an eye out for next year's Literacy Fair which is going to be DINO-MITE!

post_text: On December 9, the Catskill Central School District’s Physical Education department hosted an off-campus bowling event. Students from both the elementary and secondary campuses, along with their classroom teachers and support staff, took a bus to Hoebowl Bowling Centers in Catskill. The experience provided students with an opportunity to learn the fundamental skills of the sport of bowling and have a lot of fun doing it. Bowling is a life-long activity that can promote both health and wellness, and the trip showed students local resources available for them to play or join a bowling league. Retired CES teacher and current Catskill varsity bowling coach Lenny Reyngoudt helped host the event with the PE staff.

post_text: Our second graders made paper chains to decorate the CES Literacy Fair. Not wanting to miss out on an important learning opportunity, their teachers made the project a place value lesson; the children worked in teams to first link their strips in groups of ten and then put their tens together to make hundreds. There were great conversations about how many they needed to get to the next ten and even the next hundred. When all the work was complete, they counted the total number of links they had. The children did an awesome job!

Dear Catskill CSD Parent / Guardian,

It was recently brought to my attention that a slanderous hoax was transmitted to students via a social media platform. The post was portrayed to be from the Superintendent of Schools and fictitiously stated that a Special Meeting was scheduled for tomorrow, Thursday, November 14, 2019 to take action on a staff member who was alleged to have acted in a racist manner.

I want our community to know that this post is indeed a hoax and that no such incident took place nor is a Special Meeting scheduled for tomorrow.

In closing, the prankster has been identified and will be held accountable in accordance with the District’s Code of Conduct. Please remind your child to be responsible when using social media. Any threats and / or slanderous material will not be tolerated and individuals who engage in such behavior can face serious consequences. As always, please contact me directly with any additional questions or concerns at (518) 943-4696.

Regards,
Dr. Ronel Cook
Superintendent of Schools

Catskill’s Capital Improvement Project is moving forward, with the District on track to submit a finalized project design this December for State Education Department (SED) approval. Today, the project’s Construction manager, John Hanson from Triton Construction, and architect John Pasquale from the BBS architectural firm, provided an update to Catskill CSD’s Health & Safety Committee and SAVE (Schools Against Violence in Education) Committee about the planned construction.

A public presentation on the Capital Project plan is scheduled for the November 13 Board of Education Meeting, taking place at 6:30 p.m. in the Catskill High School Library.

In February, 2019 residents approved a $40,795,000 Capital Improvement Project to bring needed improvements to our District’s buildings, academic programs, classrooms, security controls, roadways, parking lots, and athletic fields through renovations, construction, and equipment purchases. Following SED approval, the first phase of construction is expected to begin in June, 2020.
